text:
- [Instructor] Let's
display the Amplify Studio

generated react components
within our application.

First, run your Create
React App development server
via your command line interface.
Keep this running in the background

so you can view your application
changes in the browser.

Once your server's running,
go to the App.js file.
Clean out what's there now,
and replace it with a react fragment.
I'll also delete the imports.

First, let's add the NavBar
component to our app.
First, import it,
and then create an instance of it.
When you view the nav bar in the browser,

you'll notice that it
doesn't span the whole page.
Let's change the width to make sure
that it takes up the whole page.

Now let's add the
NoteUICollection as well.
So first, import it,
and render it on the page.

Now you'll notice that
all of the notes render
and nine at a time.
You'll see that this search bar
is a little bit hidden by the nav bar.

Let's add a margin to the
bottom of that nav bar.

In the index.css file,
let's add some custom CSS
to make the app look even better.

I'll create a container,
add margin: 0 auto;
and the max-width to 900 pixels.
I'll also add some CSS for a modal.

I'll want my forms to not
always render on the page.
I'll want to only show them sometimes,
so I'll put them on a modal
so that I can show and hide them.
The position will be absolute,
it'll be white with a gray border,

there will be margin-left
and margin-right on it,

and then I'll position the
width lift right and top.

Back in here, I'll wrap
that NoteUICollection
in the container.

You'll see that the delete
button already works.
And then I'm gonna create two modals

that have the CreateNote
and the UpdateNote in them.

I'll make sure to import
the CreateNote form.

IntelliSense is doing it
for me within VS Code,
but they are imported.

And, now, you'll see that
I have both my modals
stacked on top of each other right here.
I'm going to hide both
just for the time being.
We've now created the basic user interface
for our application.
